awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: A Low-Cost, "Digital" Biosensing Platform with Single Protein Biomarker Sensitivity
awd_abstract_narration:
Accurate measurements of proteins are critical for modern biomedical research, particularly for early detection and monitoring of disease, systems biology, and new drug development. More specifically, sensitive, specific, fast, and low-cost detection of proteins biomarkers in patient samples is of importance for public health and a key component of future personalized diagnostics and therapy. To date, enzyme-linked immune-sorbent assays in all their variants are the most common sensing techniques employed to detect the presence of protein biomarkers. However, a number of limitations still exist that greatly diminish their broader applications due to the low-sensitivity, the requirement of a calibration plot to elucidate the results, and the need for advanced costly instruments for ultrasensitive measurement. This proposal aims to address the aforementioned drawbacks by developing a simple and low-cost, but potentially powerful sensor based on the integration of a two-level signal amplification sensing mechanism and machine-learning-enabled reliability.  The developed sensing devices are particularly desirable for early disease detection, ideally capable of "digitally" (calibration-free) detecting the presence of biomarkers with excellent portability, adaptability, accuracy, and high throughput. The knowledge and technology gained from this research will be disseminated to the scientific community and industry. This project will impact the education of the graduate, undergraduate and high school students by integrating advanced biosensing knowledge into their educational and laboratory training, and also actively interacting with general public and industry companies.

The proposed sensing device will allow immunoassay to be performed as a low-cost and digital (calibration-free) detection technique with potential single copy sensitivity through integration of three key components: 1) a coupled resonance between a piezoelectric substrate and a replaceable nanoimprinted acoustic wave micropillar resonance film "sticker", 2) a micron-sized mass amplifier realized through uniform silver enhancement of mono-dispersed gold nanoparticles conjugated with detection antibody, and 3) machine learning algorithms to be developed and trained to analyze the biosensing data in a reliable way, thus allowing more accurate detection. The number of the particles can be directly correlated to the number of biomarkers, realizing "digital" sensing. The developed methodology is not restricted to sandwich-type immunoassays, nor is the assay limited to any particular protein biomarker and therefore the develop sensor can be generalized as a universal platform for monitoring any biomolecule of interest such as protein biomarkers, viruses, and pathogens for assuring public health and biosafety. The work will revolutionize the acoustic wave-based biosensing platform if successful.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Electrical, Communications and Cyber Systems

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: GRANT OPP FOR ACAD LIA W/INDUS

por.por_cntn:
Accurate measurements of proteins are critical for modern biomedical research, particularly for early detection and monitoring of disease, systems biology, and new drug development. More specifically, sensitive, specific, fast, low-cost detection of proteins biomarkers in patient samples is of paramount importance for public health and a key component of future personalized diagnostics and therapy. To date, Enzyme-Linked Immuno Sorbent Assays (ELISAs) in all their variants are the most common immunoassay techniques employed to detect the presence of protein biomarkers. Notwithstanding its ubiquity, a number of limitations still exist that greatly diminish ELISAs’ broader application (e.g., low-sensitivity, the requirement of a calibration plot to elucidate the results, and/or the need for advanced costly instruments for ultrasensitive measurement). Hence, low-cost, high-sensitivity sensing devices are particularly desirable for early disease detection. This proposal aims to develop an innovative and potentially transformative technology to seamlessly integrate a two-level signal amplification strategy into a low-cost “digital” mass sensing device- called acoustic wave micropillar resonance (AWPR), ideally capable of “digitally” (calibration-free) detecting the presence of biomarkers with potential single copy sensitivity. Furthermore, a combined intelligent AWPR sensor node design and machine learning algorithms will be developed to enable high detection throughput and reliable data analysis, thus allowing more accurate detection. 

 

A number of novel features crossing electric engineering and sensing technology were seamlessly integrated into this novel device including 1) high-fidelity imprinting technology is utilized to cost-effectively fabricate AWPR “sticker”; 2) The micropillar array was chemically treated so that the tops of the micropillars will exhibit a hydrophilic property while the micropillar sidewalls will present a hydrophobic property; 3)  a super micron-sized mass amplifier was realized through uniform silver enhancement of mono-dispersed gold nanoparticles (Au NPs) conjugated with detection antibody, and furthermore, due to the uniformity of the Ag-enhanced Au particles, the number of the particles can be directly calculated based on the average mass of single particle and correlated to the number of biomarkers, realizing “digital” sensing concept; 4) machine learning algorithms was developed and trained to analyze the biosensing data in a reliable way, thus allowing more accurate detection. Finally, a AWPR based biosensing protype was developed to explore the potential commercialization of the technology.

 

The successful development of the proposed AWPR sensor would significantly lower the cost of healthcare, especially considering the large economic scale of immunoassays which are currently being performed. This proposal fundamentally advanced the mass-based sensing strategy, resulting in a transformative method that could be applied to monitoring a range of biomolecules (e.g., protein biomarkers, viruses, and pathogens) for assuring public health and biosafety. The project also involved students of varying study levels, including graduate, undergraduate and high school. The students obtained interdisciplinary training in many areas of electrical engineering, chemistry and chemical engineering. In addition, the graduate students engaged in the technology commercialization of the developed immunoassay methodology and learn about entrepreneurship in this project.

 


Last Modified: 12/21/2023
Modified by: Hongwei Sun

Image
  • The developed AWPR sensing system, consisting of a 4-well sensing unit, 3-way automated valves and their control module, electronic interface controller (EIC) with microProcess module, reservoirs and control pump, which are coordinated and controlled by a PC with a Python code.
    NSF
    Copyrighted
    Hongwei Sun
    AWPR sensing system and core components

Accurate measurements of proteins are critical for modern biomedical research, particularly for early detection and monitoring of disease, systems biology, and new drug development. More specifically, sensitive, specific, fast, low-cost detection of proteins biomarkers in patient samples is of paramount importance for public health and a key component of future personalized diagnostics and therapy. To date, Enzyme-Linked Immuno Sorbent Assays (ELISAs) in all their variants are the most common immunoassay techniques employed to detect the presence of protein biomarkers. Hence, low-cost, high-sensitivity sensing devices are particularly desirable for early disease detection. This proposal aims to develop an innovative and potentially transformative technology to seamlessly integrate a two-level signal amplification strategy into a low-cost digital mass sensing device- called acoustic wave micropillar resonance (AWPR), ideally capable of digitally (calibration-free) detecting the presence of biomarkers with potential single copy sensitivity. Furthermore, a combined intelligent AWPR sensor node design and machine learning algorithms will be developed to enable high detection throughput and reliable data analysis, thus allowing more accurate detection.





A number of novel features crossing electric engineering and sensing technology were seamlessly integrated into this novel device including 1) high-fidelity imprinting technology is utilized to cost-effectively fabricate AWPR sticker; 2) The micropillar array was chemically treated so that the tops of the micropillars will exhibit a hydrophilic property while the micropillar sidewalls will present a hydrophobic property; 3)a super micron-sized mass amplifier was realized through uniform silver enhancement of mono-dispersed gold nanoparticles (Au NPs) conjugated with detection antibody, and furthermore, due to the uniformity of the Ag-enhanced Au particles, the number of the particles can be directly calculated based on the average mass of single particle and correlated to the number of biomarkers, realizing digital sensing concept; 4) machine learning algorithms was developed and trained to analyze the biosensing data in a reliable way, thus allowing more accurate detection. Finally, a AWPR based biosensing protype was developed to explore the potential commercialization of the technology.





The successful development of the proposed AWPR sensor would significantly lower the cost of healthcare, especially considering the large economic scale of immunoassays which are currently being performed. This proposal fundamentally advanced the mass-based sensing strategy, resulting in a transformative method that could be applied to monitoring a range of biomolecules (e.g., protein biomarkers, viruses, and pathogens) for assuring public health and biosafety. The project also involved students of varying study levels, including graduate, undergraduate and high school. The students obtained interdisciplinary training in many areas of electrical engineering, chemistry and chemical engineering. In addition, the graduate students engaged in the technology commercialization of the developed immunoassay methodology and learn about entrepreneurship in this project.
